editionStmt.funder: Conversion of the printed catalogue to TEI funded by the Rector and Fellows of Exeter College.

msContents.summary: MS 189 is a folder which contains two mounted manuscript fragments removed from a printed book.

source.bibl: Andrew G. Watson, A descriptive catalogue of the medieval manuscripts of Exeter College, Oxford (Oxford: Oxford University Press), 2000.

availability.p: For enquiries relating to this manuscript please contact Exeter College Library.

msItem.author: Aristotle
msItem.title: Physica
msItem.note: IV. 1–208b34 to VI. 213b24, MS Oö in edn. by F. Bossier and J. Brams, Aristotles Latinus, vii/1 fasc. 2 (1990); no. 1974 in AL, Pars Posterior (1975).

layoutDesc.layout: Two columns, 45 lines. Ruled in drypoint; no prickings are visible.

handDesc.handNote: Script is a small, very neat protogothic bookhand, pubctuated by low point. The insular symbols for est, autem, and enim are used but the Tironian et is used and not the ampersand. Further, letters have a slightly Italian appearance and the membrane is polished in the Italian style.

decoDesc.decoNote: There is no colour but paraphs which are now brown may originally have been silvered.

history.provenance: Previously in 199.0.11 (which is now 9 K 1595), Johannes Calvin, Epistolae et responsa (Geneva 1576). Centrepiece XVI, with orn. 57. Ker, Pastedowns, no. 1849.

In a letter of 6 Nov. 1953 to the Exeter College Librarian now kept witht he fragments, L. Minio-Paluello, then Senior Lecturer of Medieval Philosophy in the University, asks whether the present item 1, then a pastedown, can be raised so that the whole text can be read for the purposes of the projected editon of the text in Aristoteles Latinus. A note of 17 Nov. by E. K[emp], then Librarian, records that the College had given permission for this to be done. A decision to remove item 2, then a back pastedown of the same volume, was presumably made at the same time.

In his letter mentioned above, Minio-Paluello states that this is the oldest existing copy of the Latin texts. This is not supported, however, by the editors of Aristoteles Latinus (above), who, in the companion volume AL 7/1, p. xxii, give priority to Avranches, Bibl. mun., MS 221, which they date c. 1180 on the grounds that it is known to have entered the library of Mont Saint-Michel before 1186. They accept that our manuscript is of s. xii.

msItem.title: Missale ad usum Sarisburiensem, cum notis
msItem.note: The text on the first leaf is part of the office for the 22nd Sunday after Trinity, SM, 193, and the text on the second leaf is part of the office for the first Sunday before Advent, SM, 195–6, including the processional of the office for the dedication of a church, SM, 202.

handDesc.handNote: The script is a gothic semiquadrata or rotunda bookhand, punctuated by low point. Text accompanying the music (in neumatic notation) is in a smaller size.

decoDesc.decoNote: Red and blue lombards flourished in the other colour, rubrics.

history.provenance: Formely a pastedown at the back of no. 1849. From the same manuscript as no. 1846 (Corpus Christi College, Φ.f.5.10). Previously in 199.0.11; see item 1 above.
A decision to remove item 2, then a back pastedown of the same volume as item 1, was presumably made at the same time as for item 1 (see above).
